hints.label: def-strong-lumpability
hints.title: Strong Lumpability
hints.content:
1257: :label: def-strong-lumpability
1258: 
1259: A partition $\{\Sigma_1, \Sigma_2, \ldots, \Sigma_m\}$ of the micro-state space $\Omega$ is **strongly lumpable** with respect to the transition kernel $\mathbb{P}$ if:
1260: 
1261: $$
1262: \mathbb{P}(z, \Sigma_j) = \mathbb{P}(z', \Sigma_j) \quad \text{for all } z, z' \in \Sigma_i, \, \text{all } i, j
1263: 
1264: $$
1265: 
1266: **Interpretation:** The transition probabilities between partition classes depend only on the classes, not the specific states within them.
hints.raw_directive:
1254: It is crucial to distinguish **lumpability** (a property of a single Markov chain) from **RG fixed points** (a property of a sequence of chains under iterated coarse-graining).
1255:

hints.label: prop-closure-implies-lumpability
hints.title: Computational Closure Implies Lumpability
hints.content:
1272: :label: prop-closure-implies-lumpability
1273: 
1274: If the block-spin transformation $\mathcal{R}_b$ satisfies computational closure, then the partition induced by the projection $\pi: \Sigma_\varepsilon \to \tilde{\Sigma}_\varepsilon$ is strongly lumpable.
1275: 
1276: **Proof:**
1277: 
1278: **Step 1:** By computational closure, the diagram commutes:
1279: 
1280: $$
1281: \pi \circ T_\varepsilon = \tilde{T}_\varepsilon \circ \pi
1282: 
1283: $$
1284: 
1285: **Step 2:** This means that for any micro causal states $\sigma, \sigma' \in \pi^{-1}(\tilde{\sigma})$ (same macro causal state):
1286: 
1287: $$
1288: \pi(T_\varepsilon(\sigma, a)) = \tilde{T}_\varepsilon(\pi(\sigma), \mathcal{R}_b(a)) = \tilde{T}_\varepsilon(\pi(\sigma'), \mathcal{R}_b(a)) = \pi(T_\varepsilon(\sigma', a))
1289: 
1290: $$

hints.label: def-rg-fixed-point
hints.title: RG Fixed Point
hints.content:
1300: :label: def-rg-fixed-point
1301: 
1302: A parameter value $g^* \in \mathcal{G}$ is an **RG fixed point** if:
1303: 
1304: $$
1305: \mathcal{RG}_b(g^*) = g^* \quad \text{for all } b > 1
1306: 
1307: $$
1308: 
1309: Equivalently, the beta function vanishes:
1310: 
1311: $$
1312: \beta(g^*) = 0
1313: 
1314: $$

hints.label: thm-fixed-points-epsilon-machine-isomorphism
hints.title: Fixed Points as Parameter Invariance
hints.content:
1320: :label: thm-fixed-points-epsilon-machine-isomorphism
1321: 
1322: $g^*$ is an RG fixed point if and only if the macro-ε-machine belongs to the same parametric family as the micro-ε-machine with the same parameters:
1323: 
1324: $$
1325: (\tilde{\Sigma}_\varepsilon, \tilde{T}_\varepsilon) = (\Sigma_\varepsilon(g^*), T_\varepsilon(g^*))
1326: 
1327: $$
1328: 
1329: **Crucially:** This does **not** mean the state spaces are identical or that the projection $\pi: \Sigma_\varepsilon \to \tilde{\Sigma}_\varepsilon$ is bijective. The macro-ε-machine typically has **fewer states** than the micro-ε-machine (information is shed during coarse-graining). The equality refers to the **parametric structure** of the transition probabilities, not the state space cardinality.
1330: 
1331: **Proof:**
1332: 
1333: **Step 1 (⇒):** Suppose $g^*$ is an RG fixed point, i.e., $\mathcal{RG}_b(g^*) = g^*$.
1334: 
1335: **Step 2:** By definition of the RG transformation (Definition {prf:ref}`def-parametrized-epsilon-machine` and Theorem {prf:ref}`thm-rg-flow-epsilon-machine`), $\mathcal{RG}_b(g)$ is defined such that the macro-ε-machine equals $(\Sigma_\varepsilon(g'), T_\varepsilon(g'))$ where $g' = \mathcal{RG}_b(g)$.
1336: 
1337: **Step 3:** At the fixed point, $g' = g^*$, hence:
1338: 
1339: $$
1340: (\tilde{\Sigma}_\varepsilon, \tilde{T}_\varepsilon) = (\Sigma_\varepsilon(g^*), T_\varepsilon(g^*))
1341: 
1342: $$
1343: 
1344: The macro-machine has the same parametric form as the micro-machine.
1345: 
1346: **Step 4 (⇐):** Suppose the macro-ε-machine has the same parametric form as the micro-machine with parameters $g^*$.

hints.label: unlabeled-remark-100
hints.title: Projection Map at Fixed Points
hints.content:
1352: :class: warning
1353: 
1354: **Critical clarification:** Even at a fixed point, the projection map $\pi: \Sigma_\varepsilon(g^*) \to \tilde{\Sigma}_\varepsilon(g^*)$ is generally **not** bijective.
1355: 
1356: **Reason:** Coarse-graining aggregates micro-causal states into macro-causal states. Many micro-histories that differ in fine details map to the same macro-history. This information loss is irreversible.
1357: 
1358: **Example:** Consider the free field theory ($g = 0$). Individual particle trajectories are coarse-grained into block-averaged fields. The macro-ε-machine describes the evolution of block variables, which has far fewer states than the micro-machine tracking individual particles.
1359: 
1360: **What is preserved:** The **functional form** of the transition probabilities. If the micro-kernel is:
1361: 
1362: $$
1363: T_\varepsilon(\sigma' \mid \sigma; g^*) = f(\sigma, \sigma'; g^*)
1364: 
1365: $$
1366: 
1367: for some function $f$, then the macro-kernel has the same functional form:
1368: 
1369: $$
1370: \tilde{T}_\varepsilon(\tilde{\sigma}' \mid \tilde{\sigma}; g^*) = f(\tilde{\sigma}, \tilde{\sigma}'; g^*)
1371: 
1372: $$
1373: 
1374: (same function $f$, same parameters $g^*$, different state spaces).

hints.label: cor-asymptotic-freedom-trivial-fixed-point
hints.title: Asymptotic Freedom and Trivial Fixed Point
hints.content:
1380: :label: cor-asymptotic-freedom-trivial-fixed-point
1381: 
1382: For the Fractal Gas gauge theory with $N_f < 11N_c/2$, the beta function satisfies $\beta(g) < 0$ for $g > 0$. This implies:
1383: 
1384: 1. **Trivial UV fixed point:** $g^* = 0$ is the unique fixed point in the ultraviolet (short distances).
1385: 2. **Asymptotic freedom:** $g(a) \to 0$ as $a \to 0$.
1386: 3. **ε-machine interpretation:** As we coarse-grain to shorter distances (finer lattice), the ε-machine approaches a **free theory** (no interactions), which is scale-invariant.

hints.label: def-basin-of-attraction
hints.title: Basin of Attraction
hints.content:
1394: :label: def-basin-of-attraction
1395: 
1396: The **basin of attraction** of a fixed point $g^*$ is the set of parameters that flow to $g^*$ under iterated RG:
1397: 
1398: $$
1399: \mathcal{B}(g^*) := \left\{ g \in \mathcal{G} : \lim_{n \to \infty} \mathcal{RG}_b^n(g) = g^* \right\}
1400: 
1401: $$

hints.label: def-universality-class
hints.title: Universality Class
hints.content:
1407: :label: def-universality-class
1408: 
1409: A **universality class** is a basin of attraction $\mathcal{B}(g^*)$ plus the equivalence class of all ε-machines that flow to the same fixed-point ε-machine.
1410: 
1411: **Physical interpretation:** All theories in the same universality class exhibit the same **long-distance physics** (same critical exponents, same symmetries) despite differing microscopic details.

hints.label: prop-closure-universality
hints.title: Closure and Universality
hints.content:
1417: :label: prop-closure-universality
1418: 
1419: Two theories $g_1, g_2$ are in the same universality class if and only if their ε-machines, under repeated computational closure (iterated RG flow), converge to isomorphic ε-machines.
